Situation1: They have argued repeatedly this week about finances.
Expectation2: Fix bugs and troubleshoot issues reported by users or QA
Situation2: A production outage traces back to a defect in their code and customers cannot access the service
Story: My phone buzzes with another Slack notification—urgent, all caps, from my manager. The production outage is still unresolved, and the root cause is a bug I pushed last night. Customers are locked out, and the pressure to fix it is suffocating. I stare at the error logs, my mind racing, but I can’t focus. My girlfriend sits across from me, arms folded, eyes red from crying. We’ve argued about money every night this week, and she’s waiting for me to say something, to fix things between us. I know she expects me to listen, to apologize, to help us move forward. But my team is counting on me, and every minute the service is down, the stakes get higher. I feel split in two—torn between the person I love and the job I can’t afford to fail at. My heart pounds as I look from my laptop to her, feeling the weight of both worlds pressing in, demanding more than I have to give.
